fields.headline: Miller time for Wolves
fields.bodyText: Wolves' frustration at their recent inability to penetrate the defences of lower-class opposition exploded in a 50-minute six-goal torrent that their manager Dave Jones felt has been a long time coming. "Sooner or later someone was going to come in for a good hiding from us", said Jones and the in-form striker Kenny Miller added: "A lot of teams had just sat back and defended, hoping to get something on the break. We saw this coming today." Typically, despite the splendid performance which kept Wolves in sixth place, Jones refused to go overboard. "If we won 1-0 I'd feel just as happy," he insisted. A "shell-shocked" Gillingham manager Andy Hessenthaler, whose team now have little chance of anything but a mid-table finish, conceded: "We played particularly badly. But Wolves are a splendid team and I'm sure they will do well in the play-offs." Miller and his front-line partner Nathan Blake tricked and teased the visiting defence all afternoon. Miller scored twice and Blake once but each could easily have claimed a hat-trick. Blake got the first in the 16th minute and the lead was doubled by Colin Cameron moments later. With Gillingham beaten for agility and creativity it became a matter of how many Wolves could score. It was five by half-time with Miller netting one and Mark Kennedy two before Miller completed the scoring three minutes into the second half. Man of the match: Kenny Miller (Wolves)
